Koine Greek is a simplified form of the Greek language that was widely used during the Hellenistic period, particularly after Alexander the Great's conquests. It served as a common lingua franca across the Mediterranean and Near East regions, blending elements from various Greek dialects. Koine is especially known for being the language in which the New Testament of the Bible was written.

For more information, refer to the [Wikipedia page on Koine Greek](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Koine_Greek).
